lead_paragraph: A doctor who worked at a Vienna clinic where nearly 800 mentally and physically handicapped children were experimented upon and put to death during the Nazi period will be stripped of a state medal given to him years after the war, the government announced. Heinrich Gross, 86, made a postwar career as a neurologist, for which he was given the award, using the brains of the dead children. Last year he was declared unfit to stand trial because of dementia.

abstract: Josh Max essay on problems he, his mother and siblings are trying to deal with in persuading his 77-year-old father, who has mild dementia and has had numerous crashes in recent years, to stop driving; drawing (M)
snippet: Josh Max essay on problems he, his mother and siblings are trying to deal with in persuading his 77-year-old father, who has mild dementia and has had numerous crashes in recent years, to stop driving; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: WE all knew the next car crash was coming, and could only hope my father wouldn't injure someone's daughter, son, parent or friend when it happened. Short of handcuffing my 77-year-old father to a bedpost, there seemed no way to discourage him from getting behind the wheel of his increasingly battered, smashed and scraped Nissan. He had had at least five crashes in recent years, all involving his inability to stay awake or otherwise focus his attention on the busy highway beyond the driveway of my parents' house in northern Westchester. Miraculously, he had never been hurt save for a black eye and the occasional sore rib.

Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to her children, Ruth and Sarah, son-in-law Robert, and her granddaughter. Jean and her late husband Albert founded the Nerken Center for Research at Parker, a nationally renowned center for geriatric research currently conducting significant studies related to Alzheimer's disease and associated dementia, anemia, depression, flu, osteoporosis, palliative care, and a host of other emerging health care issues related to aging. abstract: The scandalous life of the 19th-century French novelist George Sand seems to be an irresistible topic for movies. In this ardent, earnest costume drama (with costumes supplied by the noted couturier Christian LaCroix), Juliette Binoche follows in the footsteps of Merle Oberon and Judy Davis. Her Sand, whose long, tormented liaison with the poet Alfred de Musset (Benoit Magimel) is the focus of Diane Kurys's film, is a curiously vulnerable free spirit, and the actress's softness and warmth are often overshadowed by Mr. Magimel's manic blustering. A. O. Scott

Some of these can be more than a little annoying: sudden spikes in temperature that make the face flush and the sweat flow; soaked sheets at 3 a.m.; vaginal dryness that causes incessant pain and itching.
